overview: The purpose of this Act is to establish various criminal offenses and penalties related to fireworks or articles pyrotechnic. [12] It also amends and establishes various definitions and penalties for fireworks offenses, including establishing heightened penalties under certain circumstances. [12] The measure incorporates fireworks infractions into the existing adjudication process for traffic and emergency period infractions. [12]
appropriations: Your Committee on Conference has amended this measure by deleting the appropriation. [13] The purpose of the measure previously included appropriating funds. [13]
assumptions_and_methodology: The bill establishes a more robust continuum of enforcement mechanisms to promote compliance with the fireworks control laws. [12] This includes implementing graduated penalties for repeat or felony-level offenses and imposing enhanced penalties for offenses that result in injury or death. [12] The measure also adjudicates fireworks infractions under the same system used for traffic and emergency period infractions, which will allow law enforcement agencies and the judiciary to quickly and efficiently process low-level cases. [12]
agency_impact: The fireworks infractions system will allow law enforcement agencies and the judiciary to quickly and efficiently process low-level cases, while also allowing them to prioritize higher-level cases as appropriate. [12] The system of processing traffic infractions established by chapter 291D is well-suited to certain types of violations of the fireworks control law. [12] Incorporating fireworks infractions into this existing process should allow the judiciary to reserve resources for cases that require more resources. [12]
economic_impact: The measure establishes a fine of $200 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for the unlawful purchase or use of consumer fireworks. [12] It also establishes a fine of $1,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for distributing consumer fireworks outside of permissible time periods. [12] Carriers who violate notification requirements are subject to a $1,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine for a first offense, a $2,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine for a second offense, and a $5,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine for a third or subsequent offense. [12] [12] [12]
policy_impact: This Act amends Chapter 132D, Hawaii Revised Statutes, by adding seven new sections establishing various criminal offenses and prohibitions related to fireworks. [12] It also amends Chapter 291D, Hawaii Revised Statutes, to incorporate fireworks infractions into the existing adjudication process for traffic and emergency period infractions. [12] The legislature finds that improved enforcement of the fireworks control laws is necessary to protect the community from fire- and explosion-related injuries, respiratory distress caused by air pollution, and recurring trauma due to loud explosions. [12]
revenue_sources: Fines imposed for violating this chapter will be collected by the court. [12] Of the fines collected, the court shall pay twenty per cent to the State and eighty per cent to the county in which the fine was imposed, which shall be expended by the county for law enforcement purposes. [12] In addition to any monetary assessment, the court shall impose an administrative fee of $20 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for each fireworks infraction, which will be deposited into the judiciary computer system special fund. [12]

[12] Carriers failing to meet shipping requirements face fines starting at $1,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for a first offense, increasing to $2,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for a second, and $5,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for a third or subsequent offense. [12] [12] [12] A fine of $300 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) is established for possessing less than five pounds of certain illegal fireworks. [12] Other violations of the chapter are subject to a fine of no less than $500 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $5,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt).
